utterances: Right.
In fact, the defense secretary, Robert Gates, and the president both called it an example of the Iraqis taking the lead.
You know, essentially, that it shows the Iraqi army can carry out these kinds of operations independently, and that the Maliki government is taking on some of these militia groups.
But then, when it turned out they couldn't take on these militia groups or not take them on successfully, U.S.
military officials said, hey, this is disastrous.
Congratulations.
Thanks a lot.
So was this easy for you to figure out?
How did it happen?
Well, they've been saying that privately, of course.
And, you know, really they couldn't have stopped it.
I mean, what happened was, the Iraqi prime minister and his top commander in southern Iraq, a major general called Mohsen al-Faraji actually approached Petraeus and his staff a few weeks ago.
They laid out the details of their plan, but U.S.
military officials have told me that they weren't in a position to stop Maliki from doing this because they've essentially been hounding him to go down to Basra and take care of the problem.

Well, the main issue they had with Maliki's plan was, they felt it was overly ambitious, and they weren't confident that the Iraqi government and its army could take on the better trained and the battle hardened Mahdi Militia.
And in fact, one U.S.
military official I spoke to said, even though there's a truce now, this is the beginning of a long struggle over control in southern Iraq between these competing militias.
So what is it that the U.S.
military analyst you spoke with said was the hopeful sign?
Well, first it should be made clear, Alex, that the Iraqi army lost.
It's not a stalemate.
No matter how the government in Iraq spins it, the Iraqi army was routed by the Mahdi Militia.
But at the same time, it was the largest Iraqi military operation since the Saddam Hussein era when they invaded Kuwait in 1991.
I mean, the Iraqi army moved thousands, as many as 10,000 soldiers down to Basra.
They moved weapons and vehicles hundreds of miles, and they launched a pretty sophisticated operation.
And so even though they were defeated, the fact that they could actually do this, operationally, is an enormous improvement over where the Iraqi army was even six months ago.
But Guy, isn't this analysis, well, the logistics worked, but when they got there they lost the battle?
Isn't that really military lipstick on a military pig?
Well, you could look at it that way.
But at the same time, you could say, the Iraqi army got the logistics down.
They obviously didn't get the planning and the strategy down.

And so some military officials are saying, look, in a year, in two years' time, when they're better trained and they're better strategic fighters, they might be able to take on some of these militia groups more effectively.
NPR's Guy Raz on what military analysts are saying in Baghdad and the Pentagon about the fighting over the weekend in Basra.
Guy, thank you.
Thank you, Alex.
Barack Obama heads into tomorrow's primary with a strong lead.
A number of polls have it in the double digits over Hillary Rodham Clinton, and many of those polled mentioned the word electability.
That's a term that before Iowa was more closely associated with Senator Clinton.
NPR's senior Washington editor Ron Elving is on the ground in New Hampshire.
He joins us now.
Hi, Ron.
Good to be with you, Madeleine.
Well, Senator Obama had spent less time and less money in New Hampshire than has his closest rival, Senator Clinton, and the Clinton's, of course, go way back in New Hampshire.
What has Obama done over the last day or so to convince voters that he is deserving of their vote?
You know, Madeleine, I'm going to have to say it's less a matter of earning trust or deserving their vote.
It's more in the realm of romance or inspiration, if you will.
He's giving them a glimpse of something new, something open-ended, open-ended.

He uses the word hope, of course, and we've heard that from him a great deal, politics of hope, a little bit of an irony because that was a term that Bill Clinton used a lot in 1992 as a man from hope.
But you know, Barack is also about something else.
Freshness, a promise, almost mystery.
It is not so much about substance as it is about something else.
And according to these polls, he has pulled even with female voters - with women, pulled even with Senator Clinton on that.
Now, that's remarkable.
It is remarkable, but we saw it in Iowa.
He actually narrowly defeated Hillary Clinton among Democratic women in Iowa.
And you know, we just have to think that women would want to support the first woman with a really serious chance to be the first woman president of the United States.

And while women are among her strongest supporters and always have been, they are always also among her strongest detractors, including many women who are a lot like her in a demographic sense, people with a lot of income, a lot of education, strong career women.
They have frequently not been the people who were best for her.
Now, in New Hampshire there are - about 44 percent of the voters there are independent.
So he's got a challenge there, right?
Because a lot of them are attracted to Arizona Senator John McCain, a Republican.
This is always the big X factor in New Hampshire, and as you say, about 44 percent of independents.
They can swing between the parties.
And when they do, they can either determine the outcome in a race or the margin of victory.
And in primaries like this, events, media tests, the margin matters as much as the win.
So here tomorrow, John McCain is hoping that independents turn out for him and help him win over Mitt Romney.
And Obama is hoping they vote on the Democratic side and help him pad his margin.
Now, McCain is slightly ahead of Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney, according to these latest polls.
Whatever ever happened to Mike Huckabee?
He was, you know, he's in all the headlines as of Friday, so where is he now, today, Monday?
Huckabee has never been a big factor here in New Hampshire and he didn't get much of a bump out of Iowa with respect to that.
He's just too different from the state.
There's no big natural constituency for him here.
Southerners have traditionally not done so well in this venue.
And there are not so many evangelical Christians to provide and instant base for him.
He's stuck in the lowest double-digits and the polls here, doesn't seem to be breaking out of that into the teens.
That puts him close to Rudy Giuliani and Ron Paul in this state, so he's right in the mix with those guys not challenging to the top.
NPR senior Washington editor Ron Elving in Manchester, New Hampshire.
Thanks, Ron.
My pleasure, Madeleine.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
On the day after Election Day, we'll look at crucial issues in Philadelphia - that's crime - and in Oregon, which voted on health insurance for poor kids.
Then I brought my first car - a Pontiac LeMans.
Remember that - 1966, gray.
First though, to Mexico, where much of the state of Tabasco is still under water nearly a week after storm flooding began.
Tabasco is at the crook of Mexico's Gulf Coast; it's lowland country and swampy.
And the Associated Press reports sightings of crocodiles out of their lagoons and swimming in the floods.
Winnie Romeril is a volunteer and spokesperson for the Red Cross.
She joins us from Villa Hermosa; that's the capital of Tabasco.
She's been there several days.
Winnie, what have you seen?

Well, I can tell you that I have already been up in the helicopters to help do the distribution to communities that are completely isolated, even still a week after the heavy rains that they suffered here.
These island communities are just a little tops of hills where one or two houses still stand; all the houses in the valley are flooded.

And maybe, you know, 500 people are eking out a living and waiting for the next food drop of water, of baby formula, lentils and rice and tuna fish in cans and all sorts of different kinds of products that people need, hygiene products and you name it, we're packaging it all up and getting them out to these communities in these family kits.
We've seen really varying estimates of how many people are stranded.
Do you have any idea what the numbers might be?
It's a state that has about two million people and their estimating about half have been affected by the flood one way or another.
And also in some of these communities - I was at one community yesterday where the town itself has been divided in two.
There was a road that leads to the capital city that went between two hilltops, and so now that's all completely filled in with water.
So half of the village is on one side and half of the village is on the other.
They don't even have a boat so that they can communicate between them, and a school on one side has been converted into a shelter for 35 families that no longer have homes.
When do officials think that the waters are going to recede so that, for instance, this village might be reunited?
That's the really frustrating point for a lot of folks here who have seen floods in the past in this area but they say that this one is different.
First of all, areas flooded first that never used to flood, and it was as high as 36 feet in some places, right to the tops of the telephone poles.
And also the waters just simply aren't receding at a rate people would like to see.
I think that they have gone down about maybe a flood or two feet in some places.

They're predicting that the water's going to stay for two to three weeks at this stage and maybe even longer than that because it's still raining in Chiapas, and Chiapas is the neighboring state where there was just that horrible landslide yesterday.
And the water actually flows downhill to Tabasco.
So when it rains in Chiapas, Tabasco stays flooded.
So those are some of the things that people are really dealing with here.
They're preparing for a long haul.
And of course we all know from terrible, devastating hurricanes and floods we've suffered in our own country that recovery takes a long time.
You know, the Gulf Coast of Mexico does get storms.
I mean, it gets a lot of storms.
But still, I've heard this particular situation called Mexico's Katrina.
Were you in New Orleans or in that area during the time of Hurricane Katrina?
And can you compare these two events?
I was on the Mississippi Gulf Coast for the three weeks immediately following Hurricane Katrina's landfall.
And I can tell you that there are some comparisons, and then in some ways it's different.
Of course here in Tabasco, thankfully, there haven't been the number of deaths that we saw in the states that suffered Hurricane Katrina.

And there's a lot of helicopter support here, and I don't know all the details of how that happened in Katrina, but here the government and different states across Mexico have been donating helicopters as well as they have a large reserve called the civil protection, and those volunteers have joined Red Cross volunteers, and there's about 6,000 Red Cross volunteers that were mobilized early on.

It's probably a lot more than that because every day here in front of the Red Cross headquarters in Villa Hermosa, you'll see hundreds of people gathered who are just spontaneous volunteers there, the people that no longer have homes, and they figure, well, we might as well help out everybody else during the day when we have nothing else to do.
And so people are really coming together in a really beautiful way that we do see in other disasters.
So there's some comparisons you can make.
The numbers certainly are about equal.
The numbers in Katrina affected over a million, and here as well.
Winnie Romeril speaking with us from Villa Hermosa in Tabasco, Mexico.
Winnie, thank you.
Thank you so much.
We appreciate all the support that people are sending from around the world.
And the Red Cross has a Web-based search feature to connect families and people who are looking for those who might be in the flooded zone.
You can reach that through a link at npr.org.
